Award.AwardTitle: Artwork diagnostics: an onsite electrochemical monitoring method for early detection of coating failure
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program in the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Tami Clare of Portland State University and researchers at the Seattle Art Museum (SAM) will develop an analytical methodology, based on Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) that will permit the measurement of the coating integrity of outdoor artwork. The project aims to overcome significant barriers that prevented widespread use of EIS by the cultural heritage science community. Most notably, electrochemical testing typically requires artwork to be conductive and wired to instrumentation at an uncoated region of the artwork. PI Clare and her coworkers will fabricate and use surface-mounted electrodes that can be quickly attached (and cleanly removed) from the coating surfaces. They will investigate surface-electrode strategies, identify specific analytical parameters in the laboratory using test panels subjected to accelerated aging, and use this knowledge to conduct routine, onsite testing at the Olympic Sculpture Park in Seattle, WA.

A diagnostic tool for rapid analysis of coatings on works of art would be transformative to the field of cultural heritage science and beyond. It has the potential to impact the practice of infrastructure maintenance (buildings and bridges). Methods and electrode developments explored in this project are transferrable to any museum in the world and will allow for tailored maintenance regimens that are artwork-specific. The project provides a unique opportunity to engage the public in science literacy education, and highlight the use of modern analytical tools in the science of cultural heritage preservation. It will provide excellent training opportunities to students who wish to train in state of the art analytical methodology and in the field of cultural heritage science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outdoor sculptures are susceptible to the effects of weathering in ways that most artwork is not; with uncontrolled environmental conditions outdoor sculptures experience wide temperature and humidity fluctuations as well as exposure to stochastic events such as exudates from surrounding flora and fauna.  Surprisingly given the complexity of their environment, tools for monitoring the condition of outdoor sculptures are simple visuals: obvious corrosion, rust staining and chipping paint or clear coats. Paints and clear coats are often used to prevent corrosion on outdoor metalwork, yet their functionality as such depends upon their durability when exposed outdoors.  We have developed a method to detect the subtle deterioration of protective coatings on metals, such as porosity and permeability changes that permit the passage of corrosives through protective layers to the underlying metal.  We hypothesized that by monitoring degrading coatings, we could detect early signs of damage to outdoor metalwork, before such signs are visible to the eye.  This hypothesis was tested in collaboration with the Seattle Art Museum, with annual field measurements made at their Olympic Sculpture Park.  We have been able to classify protective quality by observing a range of values in our measurements and assigning those values to coatings having good, adequate and poor protective properties. We have observed situational differences, such as one area of a sculpture having poorer protective quality where rainwater pools compared to another area where pools do not form, allowing us to map coating quality data onto different parts of sculptures. Our work has produced data, that has been disseminated through peer-reviewed scientific publications and oral conference presentations, which demonstrates the feasibility of our monitoring method in the outdoors and in situ. The results from this project benefit the general public as they have provided information on the protective quality of coated sculptures in situ and they imply needed maintenance regimes for sculptures, for the purpose of increasing the lifetime of outdoor artwork for future generations.  More broadly, our methodology can be extended to assess the protective quality of other coated metalwork, such as bridges, buildings and airplanes.  Economically, corrosion has been estimated to consume 3-4% of the U.S. Gross Domestic Product annually; and thus, methods to assess the protective quality of coatings on outdoor metalwork can provide important data toward the goal of reducing the cost of corrosion to the GDP.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2015
Modified by: Tami Clare

    Clare lab
